sentences.text: What steps will reproduce the problem?

Going to the above URL causes a crash, I first triggered it by trying to 
get new themes from the options menu.

I've attached several bug-buddy 
reports which were generated from subsequent crashes.
Also, it consistently throws this error:
Please provide any additional information below.

Attach a screenshot
and backtrace if possible.
Note that the reporter is on a Fedora machine, in case that matters.

You can ask 
thestig@google for a preconfigured VM if you can't repro this locally and don't have a 
Fedora machine handy.
(No comment was entered for this change.
Fumitoshi, I can reproduce this bug by visiting https://www.
spotrh: could you find out what version of NSS you have?
Change to the directory that contains libnss3.
/usr/lib or /usr/lib32) and then use this command:
ukai: I now understand the cause of this problem.
HTTP client callbacks to download CRLs.
exceed 64 KB (Thawte's CRLs are 449 KB), our
trySendAndReceiveFcn callback fails and prints this error
CRLs can be as large as 1MB, so we should enhance our
HTTP client callbacks to stream response data to NSS as
they come in, rather than reading the entire response
at once (because it consumes more memory).
get correctness, we just need to modify OCSPSetResponse
to be able to give the response data to NSS in multiple
Since our HTTP client callbacks can't download CRLs, we
are relying on OCSP for revocation checking (assuming

99 to mean a pre-release of the next
version.
What are the consequences of this bug?
It sounds like we die with newer NSSes?

Ping regarding question about consequences -- is this just a warning or does should we 
be worried about lowered security?

The consequence of this bug is that
Chromium can't download CRLs (certificate revocation lists)

If a CA uses CRLs but not OCSP to revoke
certificates, Chromium won't be able to check revocation with
that CA.
I think NSS library sets the limit

How can we modify OCSPSetResponse to be able to give the response data to NSS in 
multiple chunks?
It seems NSS expects trySendAndReceiveFcn returns data at once.
What's the status of this issue?
Seems no crash regarding OCSP later than 4.
So, this is not classified as Crash bug?

I think we still need to fix revocation for large CRLs as wtc mentioned at 
http://code.

This bug is now only about being able
to download CRLs larger than 64KB.
So, what can I do to download CRLs larger than 64KB?

It looks http_response_data_len is specified by nss library and no way to configure 
the size.

Is it ok to ignore the http_response_data_len, or is there any other way to 
download CRLs?

I suspect that OCSPTrySendAndReceive doesn't need to receive the
entire response.

Instead, it should return any partial response
it receives, and NSS will call OCSPTrySendAndReceive repeatedly
until the entire response has been received.
Here is the specification of SEC_HttpRequest_TrySendAndReceiveFcn:
We should also study Mozilla's implementation of this function.
It seems nss library calls tryAndReceiveFcn only once in a session.
Am I looking at wrong place?

it tries to call internal_send_receive_attempt repeatedly, and failed when received 
size is larger than acceptableResultSize.
I also found that NSS calls trySendAndReceiveFcn only once.

c because we call the
new CERT_PKIXVerifyCert function (note the "PKIX" in the function's name).
For CRL download, I believe we're using pkix_pl_pk11certstore.
I also found that NSS's max response length is also 64 KB:

Although there is a function to change the max response length,
that function is not being used:
So the 64 KB limit actually comes from NSS?

!  If so, the only thing
we need to do is to file an upstream NSS bug.
I can take care of that.
We can leave this bug open for tracking but change milestone to Mstone-X.
I verified that the 64 KB max response data length comes from NSS.

id=526910)
and moved it to Mstone-X.
On our side, there are a few things we can do.
1. We can lower the severity of the log messages from ERROR to WARN.

2. We should stop reading the response data as soon as we have read more
than the max response data length.  This way we won't waste memory.

#1 is a maybe, because this is truly an
error.

While researching this issue, I found a few minor issues in the code,
I will write a changelist to fix them.
The following revision refers to this bug:

OCSPTrySendAndReceive should always set *http_response_data_len, even on
failure.

If the response data is larger than the acceptable size, we
should set *http_response_data_len to the actual size because we have
downloaded the entire response.
The following revision refers to this bug:

OCSPTrySendAndReceive should always set *http_response_data_len, even on
failure.

If the response data is larger than the acceptable size, we
should set *http_response_data_len to the actual size because we have
downloaded the entire response.
I fixed the underlying NSS bug in NSS 3.
The remaining work on the Chromium side is summarized in comment 19.
